conops.path: /Users/arpithaprakash/Capstone/1-2CR CONOPS&DRAWs - Copy/New folder - Copy (35)/TF TRIDENT– Platoon STX CONOP.pptx

sections.MISSION: TF Trident conducts PLT STX from 22NOV-09DEC 2023 on TA West IOT progress UAF combined arms maneuver across echelons.
sections.PURPOSE: this operation is to enable UAF to build capability through combined arms maneuver in preparation for Platoon Live Fire Exercises. .
sections.KEY TASKS:
Execute deliberate Troop Leading Procedures
Enabler Integration (sUAS, Engineers, Mortars)
Safe and efficient
sections.EXECUTION:
of PLT STX
Conduct Offensive Operations
Transition to the Defense
sections.END STATE:
UAF BTGs are prepared to execute combined arms maneuver and postured to conduct PLT and Company LFXs in preparation for Force on Force.
TF TRIDENT– Platoon STX
TRAINING OBJECTIVES Planning at company (platoon) level
Integrate UAVs to call for fire
Plan Infantry Operations (PLT & Co. Commander)
Breaching of complex obstacle (trench clearing).
Repel an enemy counter attack. Post Combat Procedures
N

draw.mission_task_and_description: Operation Trident Ready PLT STX located on TA4, FARP West, and Urban Assault Course (11NOV23-19DEC23). Non-standard training on US/NATO/Partner Army Equipment.

values: All Weapons will be carried at the low ready with the muzzle facing down range.
Soldiers are briefed on orientation downrange and how to load and unload weapons systems properly.
Ensure that a qualified medic with equipment is on site. Medic is requested by the training unit and briefed and inspected by the OIC and RSO prior to opening range.
Ensure that all Soldiers on the firing line are in proper PPE uniform.
-Safety Briefings -Lane Safety Checks
Cadre, OIC, RSO
Ensure that only Range RSO/OIC clear/inspect all weapons before Soldiers leave the CT area.
Ensure all Soldiers on the are in the proper uniform.
Range OIC and RSO commence self-imposed check-fire if a unintentional discharge occurs.
All Soldiers will be released and validated by the CP/Beachmaster
-7th ATC Policies on Range Operation -Safety Brief
OIC, RSO, lane safeties and individual Soldiers

subtasks.hazard: Unauthorized removal of Ammunition from Range

values: Cadre will supervise the employment of all weapon systems, if a weapon is possibly damaged, Cadre will certify the damage and annotate on a 2404.
Soldier weapons will be check by Cadre member before firing after a Soldier falls or drops weapon.
RSO/OIC will ensure that weapons are not left unsecured and are properly maintained.
-Cadre Supervision and Oversight
OIC, RSO, Lane Safeties, Individual Soldiers
Cadre will supervise the employment of all weapon systems, if a weapon is possibly damaged, Cadre will certify the damage and annotate on a 2404.
Soldier weapons will be check by Cadre member before firing after a Soldier falls or drops weapon.
Weapons will be restored in proper condition prior to be being turned into the arms room.
-7th ATC Policies on Range Operation -Range Safety Briefing to all Personnel
OIC, RSO, Lane Safeties, Individual Soldiers
Range OIC and RSO will identify the nearest AXP/HLZ during planning.
Each day of operations, Range OIC and RSO will conduct a "Down Man" drill to rehearse and time treatment and movement of causality from POI to AXP.
Should an injury happen, Soldier will conduct self aid and buddy aid. Medic will arrive on scene of POI and all Soldiers will take further direction from Qualified Medic.
E112 will be called and Range Control/BDE Safety will be notified of any injury for "Life, Limb, or Eyesight."
-7th ATC Policies on Range Operation -Range Safety Briefing to all Personnel
OIC, RSO, Medics, Cadre, Individual Soldier
Cadre will monitor weather and adjust uniform accordingly.
Soldiers will pack and bring ECWCS level 1-2, 4-6 as well as winter sleeping bags with bivy cover for overnight stays.
The OIC/RSO is responsible for weather calls and uniform. OIC/RSO will also update daily risk management worksheet.
GP tents should be available with bullet heaters to offset cold exposure for a continued period of time.
-7th ATC Policies on Range Operation -Range Safety Briefing to all Personnel
OIC, RSO, Cadre, Individual Soldier
Ice Sheets/Warming Blankets will be staged at various points as well as with the Medics.
Soldiers identified as a heat/cold weather injury will immediately be treated by Cadre and Medics.
Rehearsals for treatment will be conducted prior to range going hot.
-7th ATC Policies on Range Operation -Range Safety Briefing to all Personnel
OIC, RSO, Medics, Cadre, Individual Soldier
Separated by LOT number and by DODIC.
Squad Leaders will ensure proper distribution on-site.
Responsible NCO will be present and manning the ammo pad at all times.
-7th ATC Policies on Range Operation -Range Safety Briefing to all Personnel
OIC, RSO, Medics, Cadre, Individual Soldier

subtasks.hazard: Catastrophic Vehicle Accident - Vehicle Roll-overs and major collisions

values: Ensure that all drivers are licensed and trained, and there is CLS capability in each vehicle.
Soldiers will sit on seating platforms only.
Soldiers will wear seat belts and will not be seated where there is not a restraining system while vehicle moving.
TC, VC, and Air Guards wear safety harness.
All Soldier wear at minimum ACH/CVC, eye protection, and gloves. Soldiers will also wear IOTV when riding outside the hatch.
Soldiers will not be higher than name tape defilade when vehicles are moving.
Soldiers will not ride in same compartment with cargo, unless cargo is fully restrained in all directions.
Ensure all drivers are licensed to operate the equipment they are driving.
VCs/TCs ensure proper spacing between vehicles.
CDR or OIC briefs standard spacing and speed limit during safety brief, and makes appropriate changes during the operation via TSM/FM.
Platoon Sergeants ensure soldiers rehearse rollover drills IAW SOP
All UKF will receive hands-on instruction prior to operating vehicles.
TACSOP, Leader Supervision, and Daily Assessments, Rollover Drills, TRM SOP
Convoy Leadership and First Line Leaders

subtasks.hazard: Accidents with LN POVs and commercial vehicles

values: OIC/RSO will reduce speed in rural areas and narrow road ways.
Drivers and VCs will execute defensive driving techniques while driving.
VCs/ TCs ensure proper spacing between vehicles.
Standard spacing and speed limit during safety brief, and makes appropriate changes during the operations via FM.
Drivers obey all traffic signs.
Place warning triangles 300m from disabled vehicle in both directions. - Stay on shoulder and away from roadway when recovering disabled vehicles or at a halt.
VCs/TCs must stay alert and enforce safety and operating standards.
No driving on pedestrian roadways or highways should take place.
Unit SOP, TACSOP, AER 55-1, AER 385-55, and Convoy Safety Briefing
Convoy Commanders, VCs/TCs, and Small Unit Leaders

subtasks.hazard: Traffic Entanglements, Roadside Breakdown, and Damage to HN Property

values: VCs/TCs ensure proper spacing between vehicles. CDR brief standard spacing and speed limit during safety brief, and makes appropriate changes during the operation via FM.
PMCS before, during, and after all movements.
Unit SOP, TACSOP, AER 55-1, AER 385-55, and Safety Briefing
Convoy Commanders, VCs/TCs, and Small Unit Leaders
Conduct driver/TC/VC training.
New and inexperienced driver will be closely monitored in the event of hazardous weather or traffic conditions.
Driver may NOT use any device that may distract attention from driving (Cell phone, electronic device, etc).
OIC/RSO adjust speed based on driver capabilities as necessary.
Ensure operators are briefed and aware of pedestrian traffic on roads, intersections, and crosswalks.
VC enforce AER 385-55 App G, Risk Management, and Safety Spot Checks
Small Unit Leadership and VCs/TCs
Convoy speed set according to weather conditions.
Delay departure if conditions are unfavorable.
Updated weather forecasts prior to each leg along the route.
SOPs, Weather Updates, and SITREPs
OIC, RSO, Lane Safeties, Individual Soldiers
Ensure drivers get proper rest before SP to reduce the potential for traffic accidents caused by operator fatigue.
Commanders will establish and enforce specific rest and duty hour limits for operators.
Operators will be provided with at least 8 consecutive hours of rest during any 24–hour period.
Supervisors will emphasize sleep, especially the night before a mission
VCs/TCs must be observant for sporadic/abnormal patterns of travel.
VCs/TCs must communicate with Convoy Commanders if they observed unsafe behavior and call the movement to a halt to correct behavior.
Small Unit Leadership, and VCs/TCs
OIC, RSO, Lane Safeties, Individual Soldiers

subtasks.hazard: Slips, trips, falls, musculoskeletal injuries, & other misc injuries

values: Soldiers execute PLT/COY STX in Full Dragoon Standard.
Care is taken in unknown areas with rough terrain during STX lanes execution.
Additional caution will be taken when executing night operations (if conducted).
Soldiers climbing on top of tactical vehicles wear a helmet and maintain 3-points of contact.
No unharnessed Soldiers when vehicles are moving.
Lane OIC/NCOICs understand and has briefed the real world casualty evacuation plan.
PCC/PCI, Safety Brief, CONOP, Rehearsals
Lane OIC/NCOIC, Medics, Leaders, Soldiers

subtasks.hazard: All military operations will be conducted across a significant language barrier.

values: Linguists will be employed to maneuver at the PLT and COY level during STX.
Trainers will identify any UAF soldiers with English language abilities.
All training materials will be translated into Ukranian.
Linguist placement, translated materials
OIC, RSO, Lane Safeties, Individual Soldiers
Ammunition uploading conducted IAW TMs.
Operate weapon system IAW TM.
Training Support Personnel will have a dedicated area on the range to conduct concurrent training with PTU as needed.
Armorers will have repair kits on hand.
Range cadre will have additional tools and lubricants on hand.
Range cadre and Training Support Personnel will supervise all malfunctions handling.
- Safety Brief - Conduct of Range Brief - Units conduct daily PCC/PCIs
- PTU Leadership -Training Support Personnel -OC/Ts -Troop Armorer/FST -Range safeties -OIC, RSO
Educate PTU on Danger, Identification, Marking, and Reporting of UXO
EOD handles all UXO.
Do not touch any identified UXO.
Soldiers are advised never to touch anything on the ground in the training area that they cannot positively identify as not having an explosive hazard.
- Static Range Safety Brief - LFX Range Safety Brief - Unit SOPs. - Conduct of Range Brief
-Safeties -Training Support Personnel - PTU Leadership -Graf EOD 475-8332
Speed limit is based on the following: Road Conditions, Vehicle Type and Visibility.
Normal Driving Conditions:
On paved portions of the main tank trails: 60 KPH (36 MPH)
On gravel portions of the main tank trails: 50 KPH (30 MPH)
Range roads: 30 KPH (18 MPH)
When passing troops: 16 KPH (10 MPH)
Limited Visibility/Inclement weather Driving Conditions:
RSO, OIC, 7ATC Safety Office, and GTA Range Operations may reduce speed limits.
Built up areas: All vehicles reduce speed to 10 MPH when approaching, entering, or
driving in/around built up areas.
In all cases where there is a speed limit sign or other posted instructions – obey the posted
limit and / or sign.
RSOs understand the range, participate in setup, and conduct COG Risk Mitigation Brief as needed
RSOs brief all Range Cadre and Training Support Personnel the risks on their range
Trainng Support Personnel brief PTU the Conduct of Range brief, including all risks briefed by the RSOs
-Obey posted speed limit signs. -Safety briefs -Follow GTA SOP #1 -Unit SOPs -Drivers Familiarization prior to Ranges (2/2CR)
-RTU Leadership -Vehicle commanders and operators -Training Support Personnel -OC/Ts - Safeties - RSO, OIC

subtasks.hazard: Personnel injured while operating vehicle and falling off vehicles.

values: Maintain three (3) points of contact while on top of any vehicle.
Personnel will not jump off vehicles, climb off/down
Wear ACH when climbing on/off or on top any vehicle.
- Safety Brief - SOPs, Training Briefings, FM, TMs -Leader Supervision
-PTU Leadership -Vehicle commanders and operators -Training Support Personnel -RSO, OIC

subtasks.hazard: Spilled petroleum products in or on vehicle components or compartments into the environment

values: Inspect daily PMCS using sight and smell for evidence of spilled flammable petroleum products. Apache Troop backside Support Personnel execute secondary PMCS daily.
Use secondary containment devices to capture residual spills
Report all spills greater than 1.5 gls immediately to Training Support Personnel
Training Support Personnel completes and published 5 W's IAW CCIR matrix; Sends to RSO, OIC, GTA Firing Desk
-Daily PMCS by RTU and TSP -PCC/PCIs - Load plan inspections -Range Safety Brief
-PTU Leadership -Training Support Personnel -Vehicle commanders and operators -RSO, OIC

subtasks.hazard: Loss of Link (LOL) or possible loss of Air Vehicle (AV) due to multiple AVs operating in close proximity

values: 1. Keep AVs at least 200
meters above other
Ground Control Stations
(GCS).
2. If AVs are operating
within the same ROZ,
separate AVs by altitude
if approved by ATC
3. Keep GCS at least 400
meters away other GCS.
-TM -ATTP -Safety briefs
-SUAS Master Trainer (MT)
Operators will not
operate AV below VFR
minimum unless they have
an approved risk
assessment where the
weather change is
annotated
-Get a military weather brief before flights to determine if the ceilings are below minima.
-SUAS Master Trainer (MT)
Land AV as soon as
practical, disassemble
GCS and all operators
will take cover as
necessary.
Safety brief
-SUAS Master Trainer (MT)
Operators will not approach air vehicle from the rear
Operators will notify all personnel in the area of live propeller
Operators will only approach air vehicle from the front and echo the command "Battery In" when powering up the air vehicle
-SUAS Master Trainer (MT)
Operators will fly with a Master Trainer present
Master Trainer will be near the operators ready to take control of the air vehicle if necessary
-SUAS Master Trainer (MT)
Operators will only fly in approved airspace
Restricted Operating Zones will be established for 1 air vehicle at a time
-SUAS Master Trainer (MT)
Operators will operate above 150' AGL
Leave air vehicle in tree IAW local SOP
Fly above the highest point in ROZ. Do not climb tree or disturb tree. Notify German Forest Division through Range Operations
UAS Operators
Only one range entry points, all other access is closed off to traffic
All entry points will be behind firing lines
Gate guards will notify OIC/RSO of the personnel and vehicles moving on and off the range
Gate guards will not allow any personnel on the range without OIC/RSO acknowledgment
OIC and RSO will maintain strict accountability of all trainees, training support, range cadre, and visitors on the range.
-Range Safety Brief -Gate Guard Orientation Brief -Rehearsals -Range certification
-Unit Leadership -Interpreters -Unit Training Support -Gate Guards -Range Safeties -OIC, RSOs

draw.overall_supervision_plan: I assess overall initial risk to be high based upon catastrophic severity of seldom probability. I assess the overall residual risk to be medium based on catastrophic severity of unlikely probability.Most Likely Risk 1: Cold Weather Injury Mitigation: Cadre will monitor weather and adjust uniform accordingly, Soldiers will pack and bring appropriate cold weather gear. The OIC/RSO is responsible for weather calls and uniform.Most Likely Risk 2: Vehicle Accident Mitigation: Cadre will monitor weather and road conditions, leaders will execute pre-movement Vehicle Inspections, Briefs and Rollover Drills prior to all movements.   Most Dangerous Risk: Live ammunition brought to STX from previous ranges.Mitigation: Ammunition will be separated by DODIC number, Squad Leaders will ensure proper distribution on-site. OIC/RSO will conduct ammo shakedown at the start of each training day. Safeties will validate magazines and loading procedures. Range Control will be notified immediately of any changes.
